lexUnit.name: amends.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: an action or actions performed to benefit someone whom one has injured; reparation

sentence.text: He said quietly , ` Sabine , I am trying , clumsily perhaps , to make amends for everything that has happened .
A great roar from the 15th green had suggested that Andy Kyle was making amends for his disaster .
` And if possible try to make amends for the rude way you spoke to Lucy .
A week later , I am making amends at college , working out at the gym , and seeing people-friends who do not , to my astonishment , resent me .
Gary Blissett squandered the penalty in the 24th minute -- Eric Nixon saving well -- but he made amends by heading Brentford in front on the half-hour .
The Don made amends in the second innings with a memorable 103 not out and the crowds held a ` bob in " collection to buy their idol a piano .
Mummius made some amends to the Greeks by generous dedications in their sanctuaries .
And in any case , the time had come for her to make amends with Joe for deserting him when he needed her .
The Middlesex man soon made amends , however , with a brilliant save , later repeated by Hick , as the runs/time equation narrowed .
The Government have moved away from their view that everybody should pay the poll tax and are making some amends .
Lynch made amends before long and equalised from close range , but that was all the reward Southwood were to see for their efforts .
NORTH Down will put the memory of their Senior Cup final defeat behind them as they try to make amends by winning the Schweppes All Ireland trophy .
Bayezid subsequently made amends by building a mosque in front of his palace and appointed a place for himself therein .
Nenna was ashamed , but she could n't make amends , not now .
